Award.AbstractNarration:
In this CAREER award, funded by the Experimental Physical Chemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Prof. Tianbo Liu of Lehigh University and his graduate student and postodoctoral associate colleagues will study the formation and properties of interesting, hydrophillic, nanometer-sized, macroions. These macroions resemble blackberries, in that they are single-layer vesicles, composed of many large, hydrophillic polyoxometalate clusters. This will be done using laser light-scattering, small-angle x-ray scattering and atomic force and transmission electron microscopy techniques. Prof. Liu and his team will study the kinetics and thermodynamics of these interesting chemical systems. In addition to his course-development, Prof. Liu will continue to mentor high-school students from under represented groups in research projects for national competitions.

The interesting "blackberry" materials may eventually find use as biomimetic systems, or they may be useful as nanocontainers. The results of these studies are likely to shed light on other self-assembly processes that occur in nature.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims to understand an uncharted and important fundamental issue in solution physical chemistry: the transition stage between small simple ions and large colloids.

     It is well known that soluble small simple ions distribute homogeneously in dilute solutions, forming stable “real solutions”, while large colloidal particles (nanoparticles) can only temporarily and unstably suspended in solution. Both states have been well studied and different theories apply. A key question is that what happens between simple ions and colloids – in term of size and charge density. Or, the question can be modified to “What happens when soluble ions reach the size of nanometer scale”. Such macroions also have connections to polyelectrolyte (including biomacromolecular) solutions.

     Supported by this NSF grant, the PI and co-workers extensively explored various hydrophilic macroions, especially the polyoxometalate (POM) macroanions and metal-organic cationic nanocages, by different techniques. We demonstrate that macroions indeed have different solution behavior. With proper charges, they tend to strongly attract with each other and form stable, single-layered spherical “blackberry” structures with the blackberry size being accurately controlled by the solvent, the macroionic size and charge density, as well as the additional electrolytes. The assembly and disassembly of the blackberries and the transition between blackberries with different sizes can be achieved.

     Furthermore, we have discovered the connection between the POM macroions and natural (biological) systems such as proteins. As proteins and DNAs are also macroions, we speculated that they should have certain similar behavior. We noticed that the virus capsid formation was very similar to the blackberry formation, not only structurally, but also kinetically (the mechanism of formation).

     Finally, we extended our research to more complicated macroions, e.g., POM-organic hybrids. Such hybrids have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic domains therefore could be treated as novel amphiphilic materials. We discovered that they indeed possess some features of surfactants, but also have special properties due to their very large head groups (POMs).

     Almost 30 publications, with half of them published in top Chemistry and Physics journals such as J. Am. Chem. Soc., Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. and Phys. Rev. Lett., have been generated form this grant. This grant has supported (or partially supported) five graduate students and three postdoctoral associates. Three students have obtained their Ph.D. degrees and found decent positions. The grant also has supported several undergraduate students with different majors for their research experience, and supported the PI for attending several important national/international conferences. The PI has written several invited reviews in top journals, and developed a new course “Complex Solutions” for graduate students at Lehigh.
